conclusion: Both chambers have the same initial conditions: pressure p, volume V, and temperature T. The total volume of the cylinder is 2V.

The diaphragm is in equilibrium initially, so the pressure force on the diaphragm from the gas in the upper chamber equals the pressure force from the gas in the lower chamber plus the weight of the diaphragm.
The weight of the diaphragm is mg.
When the piston moves upwards, the volume of the lower chamber increases, and the volume of the upper chamber decreases.
Let V_0 be the volume of the lower chamber when the gas starts to leak. The volume of the upper chamber will then be 2V - V_0.
The pressure in the lower chamber when the gas starts to leak is p_0. The pressure in the upper chamber is p_0 + mg/V_0.
For the lower chamber: p_0 V_0 = nRT. For the upper chamber: (p_0 + mg/V_0)(2V - V_0) = nRT.
Since the temperature T and the amount of gas n are constant, we can equate the two expressions for nRT: p_0 V_0 = (p_0 + mg/V_0)(2V - V_0).
Expand and simplify the equation: p_0 V_0 = p_0 (2V - V_0) + mg/V_0 (2V - V_0).
Further simplify: p_0 V_0 = 2p_0 V - p_0 V_0 + 2mgV/V_0 - mg.
Rearrange the equation to solve for V_0: 2p_0 (V_0 - V) = 2mgV/V_0 - mg.
Solve for V_0: V_0 = 2mgV/(2p_0 V_0 - mg).
The volume of the lower chamber V_0 when the gas starts to leak is V_0 = 2mgV/(2p_0 V_0 - mg).
